channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: At Least 39 Killed in Strike on Train Station, Ukraine Says, as Thousands Flee From East
item.description: The station in the eastern city of Kramatorsk had been a main point of evacuation as the region braced for a scaling up of Russia’s offensive. The European Union formally approved a new set of sanctions against Russia, including a ban on coal imports.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Bodies were covered with tarps after a rocket attack on a train station in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, on Friday. The station was being used for civilian evacuations.

item.title: With Russian Forces Gone, Kyiv Starts to Revive
item.description: The anxiety remains, but in Ukraine’s capital, large lines of cars are now forming on highways into the city and businesses are reopening.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Leaving a subway station in Kyiv, Ukraine, last week. People are now riding the subway instead of seeking shelter in it.

item.title: ‘La French Tech’ Arrives Under Macron, but Proves No Panacea
item.description: The president has brought innovation, jobs and growth. Still, resentments fester on the eve of the presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman and Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron speaking at an election rally this month in Nanterre, near Paris.

item.title: Is Mexico’s Recall Election “Democracy of the Highest Order”?
item.description: The vote has the potential to upend the country’s political system. But many fear it will amount to nothing more than a tool for propaganda.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Posters of President Andrés Manuel López Obrador alongside a highway in Mexico City.

item.title: For a Ukrainian Journalist, War Evokes Scars From Captivity
item.description: Stanislav Aseyev, a 32-year-old journalist, had documented his abuse in a prison run by Russian-backed separatists. Now, the war reminds him of why Ukrainians are fighting for their lives.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Pavlo Gonchar/SOPA Images/LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Stanyslav Aseyev, center, after being released in a prisoner exchange in Ukraine in 2019.

item.title: Inside a Maternity Hospital in Ukraine as War Grinds On
item.description: As artillery shells fall, pregnant women are delivering prematurely, being shuttled in and out of bomb shelters or having babies in basements without even a midwife to help. Tens of thousands more are displaced.
item.media:description: Anna, 37, was comforted by her partner, Yuri, as he timed her contractions in the hospital’s basement shelter last month.

item.title: How Lockdowns in China Have Further Bogged Down the Supply Chain
item.description: China’s Covid lockdowns and restrictions are holding up truck drivers who carry crucial components among factories and bring products to ports, posing a new disruption to the global supply chain.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: A checkpoint in Ningbo, China. A growing number of Chinese cities are requiring truck drivers to take daily Covid P.C.R. tests.

item.title: Pakistan’s Supreme Court Blocks Imran Khan’s Move to Stay in Power
item.description: The prime minister will now face a no-confidence vote, which he had tried to avoid by dissolving Parliament, a move his opponents called a coup.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan in 2019.

item.title: From Dalí to Picasso, a Museum With a Masterpiece Collection Partially Reopens
item.description: Caracas’s Museum of Modern Art, a symbol of a westernized Venezuela, was dismantled by the Socialist governments. Its modest recovery offers hope to the troubled nation.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Isayen Herrera and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.media:description: Sculptures decorating the gardens that lead to the Museum of Modern Art of Caracas.

item.title: Gunman in Tel Aviv Bar Attack Is Shot and Killed
item.description: The gunman initially escaped after his attack outside a busy bar at the heart of Israel’s most cosmopolitan city. After a nightlong search, police forces said they killed the gunman in a shootout near a mosque in Jaffa.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Security forces search for assailants near the scene of a shooting on Thursday in Tel Aviv.

item.title: How the Yemen War Connects to Saudi Arabia and Iran
item.description: Yemen was already the Arab world’s poorest country before its civil war began in 2014. Then a Saudi-led coalition joined the fight against the Iran-backed Houthi militia, spreading the ruin.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: A Yemeni fighter loyal to the Saudi-led coalition at the front line in 2019.

item.title: France’s Presidential Election 2022: Your Questions, Answered
item.description: The French are choosing their president in April, an election that is crucial for France and key for Europe. President Emmanuel Macron is favored to win, but the race has gotten closer.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Campaign posters of the 12 official candidates on display last week in Stiring-Wendel, in northeastern France. Polls suggest that only a handful have a shot at winning.

item.title: Turkey Transfers Khashoggi Murder Trial to Saudi Arabia
item.description: The move will almost certainly end the last case aimed at serving justice for a heinous crime that drew global outrage.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur and Ben Hubbard
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A symbolic funeral held in Istanbul in 2018 for Jamal Khashoggi, the dissident journalist killed in the the city’s Saudi Consulate.

item.title: Killer of Sabina Nessa in London Park Sentenced to Life in Prison
item.description: The murder of a schoolteacher, Sabina Nessa, 28, added to a sense of outrage amid fears the authorities were failing to address violence against women.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial last year for Sabina Nessa, a 28-year-old teacher whose body was found in a London park in September.

item.title: Culture War, Redux
item.description: How did L.G.B.T. rights again become the subject of a culture war?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Douglas R. Clifford/Tampa Bay Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida last week.

item.title: The Electric Car Market Heats Up
item.description: Soaring fuel prices and climate change concerns are driving demand for the vehicles in Australia, as elsewhere. But they are particularly hard to find here.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Electric car charging stations in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: For This Opera Director, a Lot Is Riding on a ‘Handmaid’s Tale’
item.description: For her English National Opera debut, the company’s new artistic leader, Annilese Miskimmon, has chosen a work she hopes can bring in a new audience.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Steps to isolate Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Removing a body in Bucha, Ukraine, where atrocities have been found.

item.title: Pink Floyd Says It Will Release New Track to Support Ukraine
item.description: The song, “Hey Hey Rise Up,” is a reworking of a protest song from World War I and features the Ukrainian rock star Andriy Khlyvnyuk of the band Boombox.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: John D Mchugh/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: David Gilmour of Pink Floyd playing during the Live 8 benefit concert for Africa in London in 2005.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia’s Growing Isolation
item.description: Plus Imran Khan’s unsteady future and growing frustrations over Shanghai’s lockdowns.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: A resident of Dergachi, in the outskirts of Kharkiv, where bombing has been heavy, and close to Russian occupied territory, on Thursday.

item.title: Ned Lamont, Connecticut Governor, Tests Positive for the Coronavirus
item.description: Gov. Ned Lamont said that he will isolate at home for the next five days and not attend any in-person events or meetings.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: Gov. Ned Lamont of Connecticut delivering the State of the State address in February.

item.title: E.U. Diplomats Near New Sanctions Against Russia
item.description: As part of the European Union’s proposed measures to punish Moscow, a ban on Russian coal imports would be phased in over four months, instead of three.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: A coal mine in the Kemerovo region of Russia last year. European Union nations were discussing phasing in a ban on Russian coal imports over four months as part of a new package of sanctions.

item.title: Intercepted Russian Radio Traffic Said to Discuss Killings of Ukranian Civilians
item.description: The report adds to evidence of indiscriminate killings by Russian forces. It could not be confirmed whether the radio transmissions collected by German intelligence were from Bucha or another place near the capital, an official said.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali and Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Ukraine’s Territorial Defense Force searched Bucha, a suburb of Kyiv, the capital, for mines and bodies on Wednesday.

item.title: Methane Emissions Soared to a Record in 2021, NOAA Says
item.description: For the second year in a row, concentrations of the potent planet-warming gas jumped by the largest amount since measurements began four decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: An oil-drilling operation in the Permian Basin in Stanton, Texas.

item.title: U.N. Votes to Suspend Russia From Human Rights Council
item.description: The resolution received 93 votes in favor and 24 against, and 58 countries abstained. China and other countries had said before the vote that they would not support the measure.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: How Marine Le Pen Threatens to Upend French Elections
item.description: The far-right presidential candidate has opened up about her personal life and tweaked her policies to gain sympathy and credibility among more mainstream voters.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen during a campaign speech last week in Stiring-Wendel, a former coal town in France. She has revamped her image since the last election.

item.title: ‘Evil Came’: The Toll of Russia’s Occupation in Kyiv’s Suburbs
item.description: Land mines, bullet-riddled cars and corpses lying in the street. Residents of Bucha, Borodianka and Hostomel describe the horrors left behind by Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Ben Laffin and Benjamin Foley

item.title: Pro-Russian Hackers Ramp Up Use of Facebook, Its Parent Company Says
item.description: Hackers in Russia and Belarus are using Meta’s platform for cyberespionage and disinformation campaigns, executives said.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:description: The headquarters for Meta, the parent company of Facebook, in Menlo Park, Calif.

item.title: ‘The Daily’ explores a Covid mystery in Africa.
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man received a Covid vaccine shot in Sierra Leone in February.

item.title: Shanghai residents in lockdown criticize China’s ‘zero Covid’ strategy.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Isabelle Niu
item.media:description: Workers delivering vegetables to residents of a Shanghai neighborhood in lockdown last month.

item.title: The G.O.P.’s ‘Putin Wing’
item.description: In Republicans’ own words.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump in 2019.

item.title: Yemen’s President Steps Down, Hands Power to Presidential Council
item.description: President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi abdicated days after a two-month cease-fire took effect, signs that his Saudi allies may be looking for a path out of the bloodshed.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi attended an Arab summit in Mecca, Saudi Arabia in 2019.

item.title: Women Dominate Shortlist for International Booker Prize
item.description: Novels by Olga Tokarczuk, Mieko Kawakami and Claudia Piñeiro are in the running for the prestigious award for translated fiction.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: Finland Seizes Artwork Suspected of Violating E.U. Sanctions on Russia
item.description: The art was being transported back to Russia after being featured in exhibitions in Italy and Japan, the Finnish customs service said.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.media:description: Shipments containing works of art were stopped at Vaalimaa, a border crossing between Finland and Russia, on Friday and Saturday.

item.title: Shanghai’s Covid Lockdown Poses Test to China’s Leadership
item.description: Residents in Shanghai, China’s most populous and cosmopolitan city, have responded to the government’s pursuit of zero Covid with a rare outpouring of criticism.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Isabelle Niu
item.media:description: Workers in Shanghai during a lockdown last week.

item.title: Ukraine’s Eurovision Team Set to Tour to Help War Effort
item.description: Kalush Orchestra, a group that mixes rap and traditional Ukrainian music, was given special permission to leave the country and play internationally.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Members of Kalush Orchestra meeting with Ukrainian refugees and immigrants in Jerusalem on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: An exodus from eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A team of investigators on Wednesday cataloged the bodies of people reportedly killed by Russian forces in Bucha, Ukraine.

item.title: A leading provider of testing in Arizona is suspending 60 sites.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.media:description: An Embry Health drive-in coronavirus testing site in Phoenix in January.

item.title: In Nightly Address, Zelensky Challenged Allies to Ban Russian Oil
item.description: He also accused Russian troops of starting to hide evidence of civilian deaths.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A team of investigators on Wednesday catalogued the bodies of people reportedly killed by Russian forces in Bucha, Ukraine.

item.title: The W.H.O. warns against relaxing restrictions too quickly in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj
item.media:description: A vaccination center in Guadalajara, Mexico, on Wednesday.

item.title: Pentagon Trains Ukrainian Soldiers to Use Armed Drones
item.description: The United States is sending Switchblade drones to Ukraine, and has been teaching a group of Ukrainian soldiers who are in America on an educational assignment how to use them.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed Russian tanks near the town of Dmytrivka, Ukraine, last week. The United States is sending dozens of armed “kamikaze” drones to Ukraine.

item.title: Civilians Flee Eastern Ukraine as Signs Point to Stepped-Up Russian Attack
item.description: Alarmed by reports of atrocities near Kyiv, many residents of Ukraine’s east, now suffering the brunt of Russian force, are getting out while they can.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia, Cora Engelbrecht and Eric Schmitt
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Families waiting to board trains in the eastern Ukrainian city of Kramatorsk on Tuesday.

item.title: The Boston Marathon Has Barred Runners from Russia and Belarus
item.description: The marathon, one of the world’s top distance races, joins a long list of events from the sports world and beyond that have excluded Russians because of their country’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: Allison Dinner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The 125th running of the Boston Marathon last October.

item.title: U.S. Says It Secretly Removed Malware Worldwide, Pre-empting Russian Cyberattacks
item.description: The operation is the latest effort by the Biden administration to thwart actions by Russia by making them public before Moscow can strike.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and David E. Sanger

item.title: Russia Is Recruiting Mercenaries and Syrians to Ukraine, Western Officials Say
item.description: The Kremlin is trying to find enough reinforcements to conduct the next phase of the war, according to military and intelligence officials.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A smashed Russian respirator in Bucha, Ukraine, on Monday. The number of Russian troop losses in the war so far remains unknown, though Western intelligence agencies estimate 7,000 to 10,000 killed.

item.title: More Russians Consider Costs of War in Ukraine as Casualties Mount
item.description: Many Russians have been in the dark about their country’s losses. As news of more Russian deaths arrives, the reactions range from anger at the Kremlin to parroting the state’s messaging that blames “Nazis’’ in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: A farewell ceremony for Sergei Sokolov, a 21-year-old serviceman killed during Russian military action in Ukraine, in the settlement of Zubkovo, in the Novosibirsk region of Russia, on March 24.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Ukrainians Flee the East
item.description: As officials warn of escalating violence, the West increases sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States and its allies levied additional sanctions on Russian institutions and elites, including the country’s largest financial institution, Sberbank.

item.title: European Health Agencies: It Is ‘Too Early’ for Most Second Boosters
item.description: Additional boosters can be given to people 80 and older, who are at higher risk of severe illness if infected with the coronavirus, the agencies said.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan and Adeel Hassan
item.category: European Center for Disease Prevention and Control
item.media:description: A coronavirus vaccination site in Bari, Italy, in January.

item.title: NATO Nations Divided As Ukraine War Enters Uncertain Stage
item.description: The alliance is examining what Ukraine needs as it tries to expel Russia from the east and how to ensure an outcome that enhances European security.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A column of Ukrainian soldiers in armored fighting vehicles and tanks moved through the recently liberated town of Bucha, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Japan to Ease Border Restrictions for Some Foreigners, Including Americans
item.description: The government issued a notice on Wednesday that would “lift” an entry ban on citizens of 106 nations. But consulates are still rarely issuing visas.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Raphael Minder
item.media:description: The international terminal of Haneda Airport in Tokyo. Japan has maintained tight control over its borders during the pandemic.

item.title: A Makeup Artist Recognized This Bucha Victim’s Picture by Her Manicure
item.description: The woman, Iryna Filkina, had worked at a heating plant. She had contacted the makeup artist for help being more beautiful and fashionable.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The manicured hand of Iryna Filkina, 52, was recognized by her makeup artist teacher, Anastasiia Subacheva, in this widely circulated photograph made in Bucha, Ukraine.

item.title: For Prominent Women on Instagram, DMs Can Be a Cesspool of Misogyny
item.description: A report on direct messages sent to five women found that “abuse and harmful content is allowed to thrive” on Instagram. The platform’s parent company, Meta, said it disagreed with the report’s conclusions.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: The actress Amber Heard was one of the high-profile women that a nonprofit, the Center for Countering Digital Hate, included in its report on direct message harassment.

item.title: Countries Have Expelled 120 Russian Spies During War in Ukraine
item.description: Despite the purge of intelligence officers, former officials cautioned that Moscow would have other ways to collect information and that the efforts would have little impact on the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Russian Embassy in Washington. Governments around the world have stepped up efforts to expel Russian intelligence officers from their country’s embassies since the invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: The Powerful Force Guiding Poland’s Welcome to Ukrainians: Fear of Putin
item.description: Poland has not been a welcoming place for some refugees. But Ukraine’s cause, in this political moment, has been popular because of a mutual concern about Russia.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Refugees fleeing the war in Ukraine board a train headed to Przeworsk, Poland, last month.

item.title: Yellen Says Aim Is ‘Maximum Pain’ for Russia Without Hurting U.S.
item.description: The Treasury secretary told a House committee that the U.S. would continue finding ways to punish Russia for its invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Katie Rogers

item.title: In Ukraine, Traces of Lives Cut Short
item.description: The violence of war is often random. Those who suffer most are the civilians caught in the middle. Two recent deaths in Kharkiv, Ukraine, are a testament to that.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: A residential area in Kharkiv, Ukraine, where two people were killed by mortar shells on Sunday.
